awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for U.S.-based participants, including members of underrepresented groups in the mathematical sciences, to participate in the conference Young Mathematicians in C*-Algebras (YMC*A), to be held August 7-11, 2023 at KU Leuven, Belgium. This meeting is organized for and by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in operator algebras and related areas, with the goal of fostering scientific and social interaction among early-career researchers. In each of its previous six editions, YMC*A has provided an excellent opportunity for over one hundred early-career operator algebraists from around the world to attend mini-courses on current research topics in operator algebras. This grant significantly boosts the participation of U.S. based researchers and their institutions at this conference, exemplifying U.S. research and furnishing opportunities for researchers to expand their professional networks. Networking opportunities at the 2023 edition of the conference are supported by a panel discussion, open to all participants, which covers career advice and issues of equity and by informal mathematical discussions throughout the duration of the meeting.

The conference focuses on recent developments in operator algebras, noncommutative geometry, and related areas of mathematical analysis, with a particular emphasis on the interplay between operator algebras and group theory, dynamical systems and quantum information theory. The conference features three mini-courses by established researchers alongside many contributed talks by participants, and mentoring activities designed to increase retention of underrepresented groups in operator algebras. More information about the conference is available at: https://ymcstara.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Young Mathematicians in C*-algebras (YMC*A) is an annual conference organized by and for early-career researchers (graduate students and recent PhDs), and provides a welcoming environment for junior researchers to present their work and form an international network. The conference covers the area of operator algebras as well as applications and interactions with adjacent fields. The 2023 iteration of YMC*A conference was held at K.U Leuven, Belgium during August 7-11, 2023. This NSF grant provided funding for US-based early-career researchers to attend the conference, and thereby interact scientifically and socially with their European counterparts. This project built on the funding provided by the NSF in 2021 for US-based researchers to attend YMC*A 2022.

 

Forty US-based early-career researchers applied for this NSF travel support. Among these, the grant funded a diverse pool of 28 PhD students and 1 postdoctoral researcher based in the US. This includes 12 who identified as women or non-binary people, 4 as Hispanic/Latino, 8 from the LGBTQ+ community and 4 with disability. Seven of these researchers also contributed a talk at the conference. The funded participants were spread across 15 states across the US, including the state of Hawaii. NSF funding is crucial to the participation of US-researchers at YMC*A; in 2017, when no NSF funding was available, only 5 US-based researchers attended YMC*A.

 

YMC*A 2023 featured three mini courses by well-known international researchers: Adrian Ioana, Narutaka Ozawa and Karen Strung. There were also 25-minute contributed research talks by 24 participants, 3-minute lightning talks by 12 participants, an “ask anything session” allowing participants to ask any mathematical questions, a career panel, a lunch discussion among underrepresented genders in mathematics, a conference reception and dinner,  and half-day regional excursions. 

 

The exit survey for the NSF-funded participants for this 2023 conference was answered by 21 of the 29 funded participants. The responses provided significant evidence that YMC*A was successful in providing a forum for the younger generation of mathematicians to immerse themselves in current research, identify promising research directions, interact with senior researchers, network with peers internationally and disseminate their own work. All respondents agreed that YMC*A increased their awareness of research trends in operator algebras. And they all agreed that YMC*A increased their network of contacts within the operator algebras community. 

 

Over 85% of the survey respondents reported that they could not have attended YMC*A without the NSF funding. It was consistently reported that this opportunity allowed them to connect with like-minded researchers from across the world and have productive discussions, whom they may not have met otherwise. This is reflected in following anonymous responses:

  • I connected with colleagues based in Germany about a potential collaboration that would build on my previous research; I would likely not have met these individuals if I had not attended YMC*A. 

  • During YMC*A I was able to connect with other researchers who are interested in the same topics as me, group von Neumann algebras, who are based in Europe that I would not have had the chance to meet at conferences in the US.

  • I also found XXX would be visiting near my institution soon, and we have tentative plans to meet and collaborate during that time. However, without YMC*A, this interaction would not have happened, and it is unlikely we would have met during his visit.

 

YMC*A led to new collaborations, as noted in this response “I started collaborating with two mathematicians I met at the conference”. Many participants also commented that the career panel and discussion among underrepresented genders was informative and useful. In particular, YMC*A was successful in building connections and promoting a sense of belongingness among young researchers, as summarized by this participant’s remark, “Not only did I expand my network and meet research contacts, but I made friends whom I believe will be lifelong. There are few areas of mathematics where the community bonds are this strong, and I think this deep camaraderie will only elevate the mathematics we do to greater heights.”

Overall, YMC*A had a lasting impact on its participants. One participant said “It was a great experience and …. Every area of mathematics should have a similar conference for young researchers” and another said “This conference got me excited to do math again”!
